articles.headline: Google Takes the Next Step in Its A.I. Evolution
articles.snippet: The tech giant showed off how it would enmesh A.I. more deeply into its products and users’ lives, from search to so-called agents that perform tasks.
articles.abstract: The tech giant showed off how it would enmesh A.I. more deeply into its products and users’ lives, from search to so-called agents that perform tasks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last May, Sundar Pichai, Google’s chief executive, said the company would use artificial intelligence to reimagine all of its products.

articles.headline: Can Google Give A.I. Answers Without Breaking the Web?
articles.snippet: Publishers have long worried that artificial intelligence would drive readers away from their sites. They’re about to find out if those fears are warranted.
articles.abstract: Publishers have long worried that artificial intelligence would drive readers away from their sites. They’re about to find out if those fears are warranted.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the past year and a half since ChatGPT was released, a scary question has hovered over the heads of major online publishers: What if Google decides to overhaul its core search engine to feature generative artificial intelligence more prominently — and breaks our business in the process?

articles.headline: White House Worries Russia’s Momentum Is Changing Trajectory of Ukraine War
articles.snippet: Multiple factors are helping Russia’s military advance, including a delay in American weaponry and Moscow’s technological innovations on the battlefield.
articles.abstract: Multiple factors are helping Russia’s military advance, including a delay in American weaponry and Moscow’s technological innovations on the battlefield.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just 18 months ago, White House and Pentagon officials debated whether Russia’s forces in Ukraine might collapse and be pushed out of the country entirely.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Julian E. Barnes and Kim Barker

articles.headline: Few Chinese Electric Cars Are Sold in U.S., but Industry Fears a Flood
articles.snippet: Automakers in the United States and their supporters welcomed President Biden’s tariffs, saying they would protect domestic manufacturing and jobs from cheap Chinese vehicles.
articles.abstract: Automakers in the United States and their supporters welcomed President Biden’s tariffs, saying they would protect domestic manufacturing and jobs from cheap Chinese vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Biden administration’s new tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles won’t have a huge immediate impact on American consumers or the car market because very few such cars are sold in the United States.

articles.headline: Why Is Car Insurance So Expensive?
articles.snippet: Soaring premiums have become a prominent driver of inflation, and insurers say that more increases could be on the way. How did it get like this?
articles.abstract: Soaring premiums have become a prominent driver of inflation, and insurers say that more increases could be on the way. How did it get like this?
articles.lead_paragraph: If your car broke down two years ago, it probably became a bigger problem than you bargained for.

articles.headline: A.I. Program Aims to Break Barriers for Female Students
articles.snippet: A new program, backed by Cornell Tech, M.I.T. and U.C.L.A., helps prepare lower-income, Latina and Black female computing majors for artificial intelligence careers.
articles.abstract: A new program, backed by Cornell Tech, M.I.T. and U.C.L.A., helps prepare lower-income, Latina and Black female computing majors for artificial intelligence careers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the last 10 months, Chelsea Prudencio, a junior at Baruch College in Manhattan, got a crash course in artificial intelligence through a new program for lower-income, Latina and Black young women majoring in computing.
articles.byline: By Natasha Singer and Thalia Juarez

articles.headline: How MSNBC’s Leftward Tilt Delivers Ratings, and Complications
articles.snippet: NBC’s leaders have been forced to grapple with how to square its cable news network’s embrace of progressive politics with the company’s straight-news operation.
articles.abstract: NBC’s leaders have been forced to grapple with how to square its cable news network’s embrace of progressive politics with the company’s straight-news operation.
articles.lead_paragraph: MSNBC placed a big bet on becoming comfort TV for liberals. Then it doubled down.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: Inflation Moderated Slightly in April, Offering Some Relief for Consumers
articles.snippet: Prices rose 3.4 percent in April from a year earlier, a slight easing from the previous month and a positive sign for the Federal Reserve.
articles.abstract: Prices rose 3.4 percent in April from a year earlier, a slight easing from the previous month and a positive sign for the Federal Reserve.
articles.lead_paragraph: Finally, some good news on inflation.

articles.headline: Biden and Trump Agree to Two Debates in June and September
articles.snippet: The first debate, on June 27 on CNN, raises the likelihood of the earliest general-election debate in modern history.
articles.abstract: The first debate, on June 27 on CNN, raises the likelihood of the earliest general-election debate in modern history.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden and Donald J. Trump have agreed to two debates, one on June 27 on CNN and one on Sept. 10 on ABC News, the first onstage clashes between the former president and his successor in more than three years.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Smartphones Can Now Last 7 Years. Here’s How to Keep Them Working.
articles.snippet: Google and Samsung used to update smartphone software for only three years. That has changed.
articles.abstract: Google and Samsung used to update smartphone software for only three years. That has changed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every smartphone has an expiration date. That day arrives when the software updates stop coming and you start missing out on new apps and security protections. With most phones, this used to happen after about only three years.

articles.headline: In About-Face, Wall Street’s Big Donors Warm to Trump
articles.snippet: They may “hate the man,” as one put it, but major business players from coast to coast are increasingly on board for a second term after the first one alienated them.
articles.abstract: They may “hate the man,” as one put it, but major business players from coast to coast are increasingly on board for a second term after the first one alienated them.
articles.lead_paragraph: When President Donald J. Trump left office, some of Wall Street’s biggest names, who had taken to him during his first term in the White House, swore they were moving on from him for good. They were fatigued by his leadership style, disappointed by some of his policies and shocked by the U.S. Capitol riot. Some of them even savaged him publicly.
